## Here I am reading the CSV file and putting it into a dataframe
df = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/consumer-reviews-of-amazon-products/Datafiniti_Amazon_Consumer_Reviews_of_Amazon_Products_May19.csv')

## Printing the shape of the csv file to see how much data (columns and rows) exists within it.
print(df.shape)

## Dropping unneeded columns as it relates to the analysis/project to reduce the size of the dataset.
df = df.drop(['reviews.id', 'asins', 'categories', 'primaryCategories', 'dateAdded', 'dateUpdated', 'reviews.didPurchase', 'reviews.doRecommend', 'reviews.numHelpful', 'brand', 'manufacturer', 'manufacturerNumber', 'imageURLs', 'sourceURLs', 'reviews.username', 'reviews.sourceURLs', 'reviews.dateSeen', 'keys'], axis=1)

## Dropping any remaining null or incomplete rows/values.
df = df.dropna(axis=0, how='any')

## Running to see the structure of the dataset itself.
df.head()
source.def43b49:
## Filtering and updating the dataframe to only contain data for the Fire HD 8 Tablet. Then updating the dataset to only contain values
## for the year of 2017. This reduces the dataset and focuses on specific reviews. 
df = df[df['name'].str.contains('All-New Fire HD 8 Tablet, 8 HD Display, Wi-Fi, 16 GB - Includes Special Offers, Black')]
df = df[df['reviews.date'].str.contains('2017')]

#Prints the types of data within the dataframe and also showcases how many rows of data remain after filtering and updating. 
print(df.dtypes)
print(df.shape)
source.f8cbacd7:
## Assigns and writes the dataframe to a new csv file called reshaped_review_data.csv
df.to_csv('reshaped_review_data.csv')
source.91f9d8b9:
## Takes a random sample of 200 rows from the dataset at large. This was done to comply with the text analysis limit under the MonkeyLearn account
## which was ~300 and leave some additional room in case another round of analysis was needed. A random sample was taken to ensure that the data being
## utilized by the text analysis had a reduced level of bias towards a specific date/group of reviews.
df_random_sample = df.sample(n = 200)

## Printing to new dataframes shape to confirm that it has been reduced to 298 values.
print(df_random_sample.shape)

## Assings and writes the new dataframe to a new csv file called sample_review_data.csv
df_random_sample.to_csv('sample_review_data.csv')
